Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences in Computational Science, Engineering, and Mathematics (RECSEM).

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Research Experiences in Computational Science, Engineering, and Mathematics (RECSEM) REU site program at the University of Tennessee (UTK) engages a group of ten undergraduate students each year to explore emerging interdisciplinary computational science models and techniques via a variety of compute-intensive and data-driven applications. The RECSEM program complements the growing importance of computational sciences in many advanced degree programs and provides scientific understanding and discovery to undergraduates with an intellectual focus on research projects using high performance computing (HPC). This program aims to deliver a real-world research experience to the students by partnering with teams of scientists engaged in scientific computing research at the Joint Institutes of Computational Sciences (JICS), the Innovative Computing Laboratory (ICL), and Oak Ridge National Laboratory. International students supported by several partnering universities in Hong Kong also participate in this program. Together the students of RECSEM work collaboratively to achieve their research goals, and at the same time share a unique opportunity for trading academic experiences, scientific ideas, and cultural and social activities in the ten week long programs.

The program is organized around ideas and practices common to many scientific disciplines. The research projects are categorized into three interrelated areas of research interests: engineering applications, numerical mathematics, and linear algebra software and tools. The scope of work for these projects puts emphasis on developing skill sets in scientific model derivation, software implementation, and evaluation of numerical experiments, under the guidance of a team of experts in each scientific domain. Projects include computationally oriented multi-scale materials science and biomechanics applications, simulation of traffic flow phenomena, and processing of images using different techniques and algorithms from machine learning and data analytics. The students have opportunities to perform large-scale scientific simulations on HPC clusters as well as world-class state-of-the-art supercomputers equipped with the latest hardware technologies provided by the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE) organization, and include computing units with graphical processing units (GPUs). The RECSEM program is organized into four major activities: HPC training, research formulation, project action, and scientific reporting. These stages aim to lead the students toward completing their research projects on time during the REU period, while providing the appropriate level of motivation and guidance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes for the General Public

The Research Experiences in Computational Science, Engineering, and Mathematics (RECSEM) program, funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF), provided undergraduates with an opportunity to engage in cutting-edge computational research. Over the course of this program (2021–2024), the primary goal was to enhance students’ understanding of high-performance computing (HPC), data sciences, and numerical methodologies while giving them a taste of graduate-level research. By focusing on interdisciplinary computational models and techniques, RECSEM helped students from various backgrounds, both in the U.S. and internationally, to acquire crucial skills for their future careers.

 

Intellectual Merit

RECSEM’s intellectual merit lies in its interdisciplinary research combining computational science with various fields such as engineering, mathematics, and data science. Throughout the program, students worked on projects leveraging high-performance computing to tackle complex problems. Examples include the development of machine learning frameworks like MagmaDNN, a tool designed to enhance deep learning capabilities, and the creation of autonomous systems using GPU-based hardware. These projects pushed forward the frontiers of computational science by incorporating the latest accelerator hardware technology and state-of-the-art linear algebraic tools.

A wide array of scientific challenges was addressed during the four-year program, from enhancing image resolution with deep learning models to detecting defects in materials using neural networks. The research conducted helped to advance the knowledge of computational techniques and demonstrated the growing importance of such methodologies in a variety of fields.

Notably, students’ contributions resulted in several conference presentations and publications. These include papers accepted at prestigious conferences such as the Supercomputing Conference (SC2022) and the Great Smoky Mountains Computational Sciences Conference. Additionally, the MagmaDNN project, developed as part of the program, has evolved into a powerful open-source tool available for use by researchers worldwide.

 

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of RECSEM were significant in several areas, most notably in education, workforce development, and international collaboration. The program provided scientific adventure and discovery to 28 U.S. and 29 international students from universities in Hong Kong, fostering cross-cultural collaboration and mutual learning. Working in teams, students exchanged knowledge and built lifelong professional relationships. The international component of the program enabled students to work in diverse, global research environments, preparing them for future academic or industry roles that require strong collaboration skills.

From a workforce development perspective, RECSEM trained undergraduate students in the critical areas of high-performance computing, data science, and machine learning. These skills are increasingly in demand in both academia and industry. By preparing students with the ability to conduct computational research, the program helped create a future workforce capable of addressing some of the most pressing scientific and engineering challenges of our time.

Furthermore, the program had a strong emphasis on inclusivity and diversity. It provided research opportunities for underrepresented groups in STEM, including women and minorities. Out of the U.S. participants, 35% were female, and 18% came from minority backgrounds. This commitment to diversity broadened the reach of the program and helped ensure that the benefits of scientific and technological advancements were accessible to a wider demographic.

Finally, RECSEM’s impact extended beyond the academic setting. Some projects, such as those involving autonomous vehicle systems and cloud data analysis, have applications in industries like transportation, renewable energy, and satellite communications. These developments contribute to societal goals such as improving energy efficiency and enhancing safety in transportation systems.

Conclusion

The RECSEM program provided a robust platform for undergraduate students to engage in high-level computational research. Its impact spanned from advancing interdisciplinary research in computational science to preparing a diverse group of students for future careers in STEM fields. The research outcomes, combined with the professional and personal growth of the participants, have contributed to building a more prepared and inclusive scientific community. Ultimately, the program has advanced the goals of both intellectual merit and broader impacts, making significant contributions to computational science and STEM education.
